title: Chapter 71
content:
Chapter 71

◎Second Part◎

When Huiyin learned that her father and younger brother had pledged their allegiance to Li Cheng and brought their families over, she summoned Xin Shi to discuss the arrangements for their accommodation.

"Ideally, I’d love to have my mother and the others stay at the mansion for company, but with Elder Madame Xu and Madam Xu also coming, it's a bit tricky. You know the situation at home; our Grand Dowager has never been satisfied with me, and if any trouble arises, it won't be good."

Xin Shi, having come from Jizhou to seek refuge under Huiyin's protection and benefiting greatly from her kindness, felt it her duty to help. Her daughter was also being educated under the care of her sister-in-law. Thus, she said, "My husband is very filial. If he knew our parents were coming, he’d insist they stay here. But Elder Madame Xu has always been quite critical of us, and my neighbors, a widow and her family, live in a large estate. Just yesterday, they mentioned wanting to rent it out. I thought we might buy their house. I'll cover the cost."

Huiyin smiled and said, "I can’t let you pay for this, Sister-in-law. As for the widow and her family, let's leave them be. It wouldn’t be right to ask them to move out; it could look like we’re taking advantage. I'll send Manager Qiao to find a five-courtyard residence with a garden. That way, they'll be comfortable and feel at home."

Since her father had handed over Jizhou to Li Cheng, even if she bought a residence for them, it wouldn't be an issue.

Xin Shi thought her sister-in-law was being overly cautious, not allowing any room for discussion. The widow and her family were probably eager to sell the property, but upon hearing it involved a widow, Huiyin preferred to look elsewhere rather than buy their house.

However, it was precisely because of her sister-in-law's cautiousness and understanding of propriety that the prince held her in high regard. Not only did she keep peace within the household, but even when attending banquets outside, her husband mentioned that the prince only listened to the performers and gave them some money, never engaging in frivolous conversation with them.

"Since the princess consort has decided, let's proceed as planned," Xin Shi agreed, not wishing to say more.

But she couldn't entirely shirk her responsibility to help her sister-in-law. Soon, Madame Cui, the wife of Zheng Wuheng, would arrive. She was Li Cheng's cousin, and since she was also the full sister of Huiyin's younger brother, their relationship was even closer. Xin Shi couldn't afford to be complacent.

After finishing her tea, she smiled and said, "Since Mother and the others are coming, it's best if Xianjie stays with me."

Upon returning, Xin Shi also sent some pear flower incense, which was a favorite in her mother's room. Huiyin understood this well. Xin Shi also included two sets of gold-woven silk clothes, likely intended for Madame Cui. As for Elder Madame Xu and Madam Xu, there wasn't much in the way of gifts.

Manager Qiao found a suitable residence in less than three days. When people heard it was for the princess consort's family, who wouldn't want to sell? Some were even eager to offer it, though a few tried to inflate the price.

Huiyin went out in a carriage to inspect the place and found one she liked, priced at 5,000 taels of silver. She added an extra 200 taels to keep the furnishings, purchasing the entire residence.

Nanny Nan couldn't understand, "Princess Consort, even though you're concerned about Elder Madame Xu causing trouble, not receiving them at the mansion from the start—is that alright? You've even hosted Madam Pei at the mansion."

"You don't know. The Xu family of Donghai were originally affiliated with the Prince of Wei. After the prince passed away, they returned to Xuzhou. We don't know if they're genuinely here or if they’re here to gather information. If we let Elder Madame Xu and the Xu family stay at the mansion, they'll definitely visit, and we can't refuse them. If they planted any spies, it would be troublesome." Huiyin explained.

Nanny Nan hadn't considered this. She was mostly thinking about family dynamics.

Before the Qingming Festival, Madam Ji and the others arrived at the residence bestowed by Huiyin. Nanny Nan personally received them, "The princess consort bought this residence in anticipation of your arrival. The best feature of this house is the well-tended flowers and trees in the garden. The main gate is centrally located, and the carved window frames in the main rooms are exquisite. The furnishings are all ready. After you’ve freshened up, there will be a welcoming banquet at the mansion."

"The princess consort still thinks of us despite her many responsibilities. How wonderful," Madam Ji said, reciting a Buddhist prayer. She thought her daughter was truly considerate. Now, living independently, she was still the head of the household, which made her feel much more at ease.

Nanny Nan warmly added, "The princess consort specifically sent me to serve you. We'll go to the mansion together later."

When they entered the residence, Elder Madame Xu, being of high seniority, was given the best courtyard in the east. The main courtyard had five small, delicate rooms with an additional three side rooms in the east and a back house. The steward of the residence smiled and said, "The princess consort said this place is warm in winter and cool in summer, a perfect spot. The back house will be for Madam Xu, so you'll have someone to talk to."

When Elder Madame Xu rested in the inner room, she found the bedding, furnishings, and clothes all ready, along with a huanghuali chest and a zitan wood bed. The curio cabinet was filled with various treasures, leaving her with no room for complaints. However, the back house where Madam Xu stayed had only three small rooms, furnished with red sandalwood that looked bright but wasn't of high quality.

A servant girl named Qiuyan, known for her cunning ways, noticed Madam Xu's dissatisfaction and said, "She’s not treating you with the respect you deserve. I just visited Madam Ji's courtyard, where there were beautiful flowers, rare animals, and trays of jade and pearl curtains. Your accommodations are only slightly better than Madam Ji's attendant."

"What can I do?" Madam Xu wasn't foolish. Although she and Elder Madame Xu stirred up trouble, it was just to cause unease. If she had to confront Madam Ji directly, she knew Madam Ji wouldn't hold back.

Qiuyan secretly cursed under her breath before running out.

As for Madam Ji, who loved lively gatherings and disliked solitude, she was delighted by the intricate flower basket placed on the flower stand—a woven grass basket filled with forsythia, weeping cherry, white peach blossoms, yellow roses, and dogwood, creating a beautiful and lively scene.

Nanny Nan, seeing Madam Ji's delight, smiled and said, "The princess consort personally arranged this and sent it over."

"How is the princess consort?" Madam Ji asked quietly, noticing the absence of others.

Nanny Nan sighed, "The prince has been away at war for years, as you know. The Grand Dowager previously forced our princess consort to kneel. If only you were coming, the princess consort would have invited you into the mansion. But with Elder Madame Xu's temperament, if the Grand Dowager Wu found any fault, how could our princess consort maintain her standing in the mansion?"

Madam Ji slapped her thigh and exclaimed, "You're right, I was so confused I didn't think of this. I don’t think Xu Shi needs to go. She has already left her husband's family, so why should she go? It would only give people something to gossip about."

Seeing that Madam Ji was on the same page, Nanny Nan nodded and quietly added, "My biggest worry is that the Xu family of Donghai might be spying for someone. Elder Madame Xu and Xu Shi are both from the Xu family, and they might not be defensive towards them."

Madam Ji's expression turned serious.

Meanwhile, Huiyin had invited Xin Shi to accompany her and had also spoken to Grand Dowager Wu, asking her to come over. When Grand Dowager Wu heard that the Prince of Huaiyin had given Jizhou to Li Cheng, she prepared a few treasures to bestow upon others.

Originally, they had all relied on Prince Wei. If her grandson ever becomes emperor, this beautiful dream might come true, and she would become the empress dowager.

The most revered woman in all of Da Ye, something she hadn't dared to imagine before.

By the time Madam Ji and the others arrived, dusk had settled in. Miss Cui, wearing a pendant crown and a brocade robe, was supporting Madam Ji. When Madam Ji saw her daughter, she was momentarily taken aback.

Huiyin, however, started crying, "Mother, I’m so glad you’re finally here."

Both Madam Ji and Miss Cui started crying as well. Madam Xin, holding her belly, came over to console them. Seeing her large belly, Madam Ji quickly asked, "Guge’s mother, is it true that you're with child?"

"Yes, I'm just starting to show. Madam, have you seen my husband? He keeps saying he's unfilial, and there's nothing we can do," Madam Xin said while wiping her tears.

Madam Ji shook her head, "No mother would ever blame her child."

Huiyin then spoke with Miss Cui and exchanged a few pleasantries with Elder Madame Xu so as not to appear cold towards anyone.

"Let's go pay our respects to the dowager first, then we'll sit for the banquet."

Everyone went to pay their respects to Grand Dowager Wu, and then Elder Madame Xu, Madam Ji, and Miss Cui entered the main hall. They saw an old lady sitting in the upper seat, wearing a wide-sleeved ceremonial robe, with a jade pendant at the hem, a gold phoenix hairpin in her coiled hair, looking extremely dignified.

Grand Dowager Wu smiled and said, "Please, don't stand on ceremony, relatives."

Elder Madame Xu bowed immediately and said, "I have caused much disturbance by coming here, please don't take offense, Grand Dowager."

After some polite exchanges, they took their seats as host and guest. Miss Cui, however, stood by her mother-in-law's side, unwilling to sit. Seeing this, Huiyin said, "Today, you are a guest, there's no need to serve, please sit."

Only then did Miss Cui reluctantly sit down.

The banquet had all kinds of delicacies, but Elder Madame Xu's thoughts were not on the food. Earlier, Madam Ji had decided that Xu Shi shouldn't come. She had chosen to remain silent because she couldn't afford to fall out with Madam Ji over such a trivial matter.

If she privately asked Huiyin for help, she would definitely be turned down and would never agree. But if it were in front of Grand Dowager Wu, everything would be easier to handle.

After the banquet, everyone rinsed their mouths, and Grand Dowager Wu spoke with the group.

Elder Madame Xu seemed eager to please Grand Dowager Wu. They were of similar age and both came from humble backgrounds, experiencing a sudden rise to wealth. From the capital to Xuzhou, they had a lot in common.

"The current performances in Shangjing are different from back then. The tunes are drawn out, and the ornamentations are gone..." Elder Madame Xu said with a smile.

Grand Dowager Wu also sighed, "I haven't been back to Shangjing for many years since my son was enfeoffed."

Seizing the opportunity when Grand Dowager Wu mentioned Shangjing, Elder Madame Xu subtly conveyed her intentions, "You are truly blessed. Prince Wu is filial, and the Prince of Huaiyin is extraordinarily brave. Nowadays, everyone admires the Prince of Huaiyin. Even my granddaughter, who married the crown prince as a Liangdi, feels that the crown prince doesn't amount to much. If only we could bring her here, it would show the world that righteousness brings many supporters, while injustice brings few."

title: Chapter 72
content:
Chapter 72

◎Combined Double Chapters◎

As soon as elder Madame Xu spoke, Hui Yin sneered. She thought to herself that there really was a kind of fate between people. Elder Madame Xu wasn’t even this attentive to her own son, let alone her granddaughter. If she were really thinking of Zheng Fang, she shouldn’t have said something like that at this moment.

By saying these words in front of Grand Dowager Wu, she was clearly implying that Zheng Fang was hedging his bets.

Sure enough, Grand Dowager Wu was displeased and found elder Madame Xu absurd. Just as she was about to say something, Hui Yin continued, "Elder Madame Xu, aren't you putting the prince in a difficult position? The prince is acting on behalf of the people of the world; how could he possibly take the Crown Prince's wife? If you're really worried that my elder sister will be tormented because her father has sided with our prince, we will do our best to find out in the future. But speaking like this now, how will people gossip about our prince?"

Elder Madame Xu often did inexplicable things for the sake of De Yin. After hearing everything, Grand Dowager Wu felt that all the heroes of the world were fighting for her grandson, but they were tarnishing their reputation over some woman.

"Your Zheng family’s women are unwanted. There’s already a granddaughter-in-law with the surname Zheng, keeping her grandson away from the light of day. Now another Zheng woman is coming. Is there no way to live?" Thus, she continued, following Hui Yin’s lead, "Exactly, Elder Madame Xu, just wait for the future."

Elder Madame Xu didn’t expect Hui Yin to frame the rescue of her sister as if it were for De Yin’s sake, and that Li Cheng’s reputation would be tarnished. Hui Yin was deliberately using reputation as an excuse, which also showed that she knew De Yin had always been better than her. If De Yin were to leave the palace, she would be uneasy.

Just as she was about to say more, Madame Ji interrupted and quickly changed the subject. She deeply resented her mother-in-law. If you love De Yin so much and are willing to accompany her, why didn’t you go to the Eastern Palace with her? You left more quickly than anyone else, afraid they wouldn’t bring Xu Shi along.

Grand Dowager Wu, being elderly and lacking in spirit, sat for a while before showing signs of fatigue. Seeing this, Hui Yin had Nanny Fan arrange for her to be carried back in a sedan chair.

She then sent someone to escort elder Madame Xu to the guest room and stayed behind to speak with Madame Ji and Madame Cui.

Madame Ji thought Hui Yin would speak ill of elder Madame Xu, but instead, she asked, "How has Shi Chong become so powerful now?"

"Let’s not even discuss it. He even provoked your father, who took up the challenge and didn’t think much of him, only to be defeated. Afterward, he kept provoking, and your father also said that Shi Chong was behind the bandit troubles in Jizhou. He did it on purpose." Madame Ji was still somewhat angry as she spoke.

Hui Yin, however, remained calm. "If you're not as skilled as someone, it's not about intentionality. I think Shi Chong alone doesn’t have that much capability; the Crown Prince must be supporting him behind the scenes. Now that Father and the brothers are preparing to follow the prince, they shouldn’t have second thoughts. Otherwise, even I won’t be able to help them."

She understood her father’s character very well. If he truly had the strength to look down on the world, that would be one thing, but if not, and he wavered again, she wouldn’t be able to control what would happen to Li Cheng in the future.

Madame Ji was greatly alarmed and quickly said, "Daughter, don’t worry, your father definitely won’t."

Cui Yuehua had always thought that Hui Yin was sharp and commanding, not one to be submissive. Seeing her now, having arranged everything properly and speaking with an air of authority, even speaking bluntly about her own parents, Yuehua didn’t dare to say a word more.

Seeing her mother agree, Hui Yin nodded. "It’s late today. You can stay overnight at the mansion and have breakfast tomorrow before returning to organize things. I also have some items to send over."

"Thank you, Princess," Madame Ji quickly replied.

After finishing the official matters, Hui Yin smiled and said, "Mother, why call me Princess? Privately, just call me by my name. Just now, with the two elders present, we couldn’t relax. At this time, I’ve specially arranged for someone to prepare yogurt, melons, fruits, and pastries in the small hall. Let’s go and have some more, and we can have a good chat."

They strolled through the garden, passing by fields of peonies, rose trellises, and fragrant wooden pavilions. The breeze brought the scent of flowers, and after passing a screen wall, they saw lush green bamboo, towering pines, pavilions, and buildings, a picture of wealth and prosperity.

Madame Ji noticed that after her daughter led them into the main courtyard, she had someone lock the gate and said, "Why is it locked at night?"

Usually, a few old women would be enough to watch over it.

Hui Yin said, "My husband has been away from home for a long time. If the doors aren’t secure, something might happen, and the servants will surely gossip. As they say, human words are to be feared."

Despite having two children, Li Cheng’s rising status meant many sought to find fault with her, offering themselves to him.

"I see, now that we’re here, you’ll have a helping hand," Madame Ji thought of how her daughter had married far away and had to be cautious because she lacked assistance.

Hui Yin led Madame Ji and her daughter-in-law to the steps and inside, where red candles were lit, as bright as day.

Cui Yuehua noticed the light and shadows moving on the walls and, upon closer inspection, saw two glass lanterns.

On the table were six elegant silver platters, each holding a large bunch of purple grapes, yellow golden oranges with green leaves, egg-sized lychees with mist still rising from their red shells and white flesh, sliced white pears, two other fresh fruits, a platter of dried meat, another of dried fruits, and several fashionable pastries.

They sat according to rank, having just eaten a greasy banquet, and now the fresh fruit dishes were very refreshing.

Huiyin asked Miss Cui, "How is my nephew?"

Miss Cui immediately put down her chopsticks and replied, "He’s doing well, thank you for asking, elder sister."

"Guge is studying, and your child is still young, so take good care of him for now. By the way, how is Erlang treating you?" Huiyin asked with a smile.

There was no need to elaborate on her close relationship with Zheng Wuheng; she simply said that her husband treated her well, especially in front of Huiyin's elder sister.

After drinking a cup of yogurt, Huiyin said, "Now that Erlang has gone to fight with your brother-in-law, you should stay at home and take good care of your mother-in-law. If you want to have some fun, just come over to my place."

When she mentioned Miss Cui earlier, Xin Shi’s reaction was awkward, so Huiyin knew there was some discord between them. She didn’t suggest Miss Cui go to see Xin Shi but instead invited her to come here for fun. Xin Shi and Miss Cui were sisters-in-law, and it was normal for them to not get along. Otherwise, why would her brother have traveled so far to seek refuge with her? However, she and Zheng Wuheng got along very well. Relatives who lived apart often maintained a closer bond, but too much proximity could cause problems.

Hearing this, Miss Cui quickly agreed and offered some flattering words.

Madame Ji, having drunk a cup of wine, felt tired and instructed Huiyin, "In a few days, when I’ve settled things, I’ll invite the princess and your children to come over for a visit."

"I will definitely go. With you and my sister-in-law here, I won’t feel lonely anymore. Let me first explain the situation with the officials' families in Xuzhou to you..."

They talked for half an hour before resting.

The next day, after arranging breakfast, Madame Ji, Elder Madame Xu, and Miss Cui went home together.

Elder Madame Xu had not slept well and, upon returning home, spoke to Xu Shi about it. "I suggested bringing Deyin back, but the second girl disagreed and spoke quite harshly. I see that Grand Dowager Wu is not a manager. The entire Huaiyin Mansion is essentially run by the second girl."

"Alas, it's truly 'when it rains, it pours,'" Xu Shi replied helplessly.

Similarly, Xie Jiuyi, upon learning that Wei Duo’s forces had advanced without warning, also mobilized his troops. With the passing of the Guo brothers, some civil officials feared Wei Duo. Some suggested that the Prince of Yuzhang should surrender to Wei Duo since the Weis were related by marriage. Others proposed surrendering to the Prince of Huaiyin.

As the discussion heated up, they heard that the brother of Xu Cifei had surrendered to Wei Duo, bringing the second son of the Prince of Wei with him.

It was one disaster after another.

Upon seeing Xie Jiuyi return and prepare for another campaign, Yin Liyi said, "My lord, the people in Jianye are uneasy. With our vast territory, why are they even considering surrender?"

"Alas, although I assist the Prince of Yuzhang, I am not the prince. If the master cannot command respect, I have no choice but to take on more burdens," Xie Jiuyi replied. He had previously rejected the Cao family’s money for his own reasons but ended up losing both his wife and the battle. Later, many heard that Li Cheng’s attack on Yanzhou was supported by the Cao family, who said he shouldn’t have lost his composure over a woman.

Yin Liyi didn’t think much of it; she believed that if Li Cheng could defeat Wei Duo, her husband should at least be able to hold him off. She began packing again.

However, Wei Duo was well-prepared to attack Jianye. For now, he couldn’t move against Li Cheng, as Jizhou was now under his control, with many capable subordinates. The Prince of Yuzhang was just a child; if not now, when? He could also take Jingzhou in the process.

Once relatives, the Prince of Wei had now become an enemy after his death.

Although Yin Lifang had her brother-in-law’s help, she was still very afraid. Yin Liyi comforted her elder sister, "Why are you so scared? With your brother-in-law here, he will drive Wei Duo away."

"War is very unpredictable. If we can’t hold this territory, I will have failed the Prince of Wei," Yin Lifang said, wiping her tears.

Her skills were limited to the inner chambers, and she knew nothing of war. Now, her only reliance was Xie Jiuyi. He was trustworthy, but if something were to happen, she wouldn’t know what to do.

The two were like headless flies. Meanwhile, Li Cheng, along with Zheng Fang and Pei Shuo, confronted Shi Chong’s army. After an initial battle, Shi Chong realized that Li Cheng and Zheng Fang’s military discipline was very different from his own. Li Cheng commanded his father-in-law with ease. Under Li Cheng’s leadership, Zheng Fang became more organized. Shi Chong held a small territory and reported to the Crown Prince. Li Cheng didn’t prolong the battle and returned to Xuzhou with his father-in-law and others.

A month later, when he returned, Huiyin had accepted an invitation from Madame Ji to visit the Zheng family for a drink and attended a wedding banquet at the Xue family.

After Xue Huanhuan finished her mourning period, the Xue family found her a match. With a substantial dowry and her beautiful appearance, she married well.

As long as a woman had some money, a good family background, and family support, life would generally be good.

When Li Cheng returned, it was the height of summer. Huiyin had originally planned to send Grand Dowager Wu to a villa to escape the heat, but the Grand Dowager Wu was too lazy to move. Huiyin had a shaded pavilion built in front of the Grand Dowager Wu’s room, decorated with rose and grape vines, creating an interesting and pleasant atmosphere. The Grand Dowager Wu was delighted and began spending her evenings cooling off under the pavilion.

However, Huiyin didn’t expect the old woman to speak well of her. Once Li Cheng returned, they would be in opposition again.

Upon hearing that Li Cheng was back, she hurriedly ordered the servants to prepare a banquet and changed into a new outfit to welcome him personally. This time, Li Cheng had managed to reclaim most of Jizhou without much difficulty.

“Huiyin,” seeing her welcome him made him feel even more comforted.

Smiling, Huiyin walked alongside him and said, “I didn’t expect you to return so soon. My grandmother and mother have come over and bought a new house for them to settle down.”

Li Cheng asked, “Is the house good? For your father-in-law and mother-in-law, it must be a fine residence.”

“Rest assured, it is a five-courtyard house with a garden. It was previously owned by a former governor, and I have renovated it,” Huiyin replied.

The couple entered the house together, and Li Cheng took out several ledgers from his bosom. “These need to be brought in overnight. A large sum of money was spent from our internal treasury for the war in Yanzhou last time.”

Though Li Cheng usually spoke in a bold manner, he was actually very meticulous.

Huiyin nodded, “Don’t worry, I will keep them safe.”

After changing his boots and clothes, Li Cheng spoke to Huiyin again, “Do you know who is behind Shi Chong? It’s the Crown Prince causing trouble. He supplied those bandits with good weapons, allowing them to loot the people. I disapprove of this, so I attacked a few of their hideouts. However, Shi Chong is clever; after occupying a small piece of land, he stopped fighting. I’ve been at war for many years, and you advised me to rest and recuperate, so I didn’t pursue him further.”

“I agree. As the saying goes, preserving our strength is key. We already control a large amount of land, and if we can govern it well, it will become impregnable in the future,” Huiyin said, glad that Li Cheng wouldn’t have to go out to battle recently.

The couple’s harmonious relationship needed no further mention.

The next day, Li Cheng attended a victory banquet at the military camp, introducing his father-in-law and brother-in-law to everyone. It was Zheng Fang’s first time at Li Cheng’s military camp, and although the others joked, they didn’t dare to be presumptuous.

It was said that alcohol was only allowed during celebrations after a victory. Each person attended to their duties without disobeying orders. Zheng Wuheng had always been close to Li Cheng, and after this war to reclaim Jizhou, his admiration for his brother-in-law grew even more. He was able to fight side by side with his brother, and the two of them came together to toast Li Cheng.

Li Cheng drank a cup and said with a smile, “In the future, let’s all work together in the military.”

Pei Shuo and Zheng Wuheng responded in unison, “Yes, sir.”

As for Zheng Fang, he got drunk and was helped home by his two sons. He had contributed significantly, but he was like a spent arrow, not taking care of himself. He had held out outside but collapsed once he returned home, falling asleep on Madame Ji’s bed.

With a hot towel on his face, Madame Ji scolded him, “You drank until your face was red. Your son said he couldn’t even persuade you to stop.”

“Ah, I finally feel relieved. I don’t want to waste my energy thinking about whether to shamelessly ask my son-in-law to give me Jizhou,” Zheng Fang said, feeling a bit more sober after removing the hot towel.

When Zheng Fang brought up his recurring thoughts, Madame Ji remembered Huiyin’s advice and quickly said, “Our daughter said that if you keep changing your mind, even she won’t be able to help you.”

Zheng Fang, flustered, said, “When have I changed my mind?”

“One must accept aging. Since you can no longer be as active as before, relying on your son-in-law is not a bad thing. He is a distinguished figure, of royal lineage, a legitimate member of the Li family,” Madame Ji advised.

If anyone didn’t want to stand independently, Madame Ji often talked about wanting to return to their hometown with Zheng Fang, but in reality, they couldn’t really leave their daughter’s side.

Zheng Fang understood, “Ever since I entrusted these matters to my son-in-law, I’ve felt much lighter. Before, I was so worried I couldn’t sleep. I thought it was due to drinking and indulgence, so I abstained for a few days, but it didn’t help. Now, I truly feel much lighter.”

Madame Ji smiled, “We’re old, and it’s time to leave things to the younger generation. Rest well.”

Seeing her husband become more alert after drinking the tea, Madame Ji said, “You don’t know, last month when we first arrived, your mother mentioned to the Empress Dowager about asking our son-in-law to save De Yin. I know De Yin is her favorite, but the Empress Dowager already has some reservations about Huiyin. If she finds out you’re playing both sides, what will happen in the future? Although our son-in-law treats our daughter well now, he will gain more power and have many beautiful women around him. Even small mistakes might be magnified. The other day, I invited De Yin over for a drink at our house. I know she is cautious and has prevented many disasters, saying that with us here, she has support.”

In fact, Huiyin had always been very insightful and opinionated. She could manage household affairs for Madame Ji and was capable of riding horses and composing poetry outside. She often hit the mark with her words.

Although Zheng Fang had sons, Zheng Wuheng had always been childish and wasn’t as steady and incisive as his sister.

Now that their entire family had turned to their son-in-law, it wasn’t a random decision. Naturally, they relied on their daughter, and there were benefits to it. Now hearing Madame Ji’s words, he asked, “Why did mother say that?”

"Mother only cares about De Yin. When this marriage proposal came, we hadn’t even said anything, but the elder Madame Xu had already taken the eldest miss there without hesitation. I didn’t expect that this time, it was the Crown Prince behind the mischief. We’re barely holding on ourselves, and now we’re relying on others. What right do we have to make demands? Even if you hadn’t offered Jizhou, Shi Chong might have taken it anyway. Rather than that, it’s better to give it to our righteous son-in-law." Madame Ji spoke frankly, expressing her thoughts directly.

They had come to rely on others because they couldn’t manage on their own. What right did they have to control De Yin?

Zheng Fang sighed, "Even if we want to save De Yin, it will have to be in the future. I don’t have any methods now."

Madame Ji sneered, "Your ears are always soft. Let me tell you, don’t be foolish now. We don’t have the ability to take people from the Crown Prince."

"Alright, alright," Zheng Fang said.

The next day, he went to pay his respects to elder Madame Xu again. He saw Xu Shi standing before the elder Madame Xu, serving her. Xu Shi wore a bluish-purple vest and had a bridge-style hairpin in her hair, with two jade bracelets loosely worn on her wrists. Zheng Fang, who had many wives and concubines, could easily see that Xu Shi had deliberately applied makeup. Yet, he sat there, unmoved.

It wasn’t just because Xu Shi was older—though that was part of it. It was because seeing Xu Shi reminded him of Madame Ji. Madame Ji had once threatened to hang herself when he considered taking Xu Shi back at the elder Madame Xu’s behest.

Though she appeared calm now, Madame Ji had a fiery temper. She didn’t mind his other concubines but disliked Xu Shi, saying she wasn’t a good person.

There was tension between elder Madame Xu and both Madame Ji and Huiyin, but she spoke frankly to her son.

"Your heart has no place for your eldest daughter. We’ve all left, yet we’ve abandoned her there alone. Is this how a father should act?" Elder Madame Xu, as Madame Ji had predicted, brought up the old tune again.

Zheng Fang rubbed his temples and said, "Mother, if I had the ability, would I be relying on my young son-in-law at my age? Begging for a living behind him?"

Elder Madame Xu’s eyes flickered with irritation. This was the old Zheng Fang—someone with ambition but raised in the marketplace, always honest. He had only started putting on airs after gaining power. Now, it seemed he had reverted to his former self. She was a strict mother. In the past, she would have scolded him for being useless. But now that she was old and had to rely on him, she could only gently advise, "We haven’t reached such a point yet. You are still a local ruler."

"I’m not anymore, Mother," Zheng Fang said, and then took his leave.

As soon as he left, Elder Madame Xu jumped in anger. "Look at him, a spineless coward who’s afraid of his own wife!"

Xu Shi felt a pang in her heart. She was his wife, after all!

The aunt and niece were helpless.

As for Zheng Fang, not wanting to return to the house and face Elder Madame Xu’s nagging, he went straight to Pei Shuo’s place. Seeing Zheng Fang arrive, Pei Shuo had Xin Shi invite two singers over and prepared a feast for the two men to dine together.

Zheng Fang, burdened with many worries, could only vent to Pei Shuo, who lived a simple life with his family. Pei Shuo, having come to rely on his sister, was wholeheartedly working for Li Cheng. Hearing Zheng Fang’s concerns, he said, "Father, why bother with her? If the prince truly ascends the throne one day, my sister will be the empress. If our elder sister has the fortune, she will naturally be taken care of. If the prince fails, we’ll all be prisoners. It’s better to side with the Crown Prince then."

"Good son, that’s truly enlightening," Zheng Fang said, feeling no guilt at all.

Compared to Zheng Fang, who would soon shake off any pangs of conscience and feel no psychological burden, most people were different. Li Cheng was a normal person. Though he had set up his own household, he was still worried when he heard that Xie Jiuyi’s messenger had been injured by Wei Duo.

"I’m worried that Xie Jiuyi won’t be able to hold his ground. It’s likely that the Prince of Yuzhang won’t live much longer," Li Cheng sighed deeply.

Huiyin handed him a pair of silver-white silk shoes embroidered with cranes and thought of Li Jing. "It’s also pitiful. When the Prince of Wei was alive, he didn’t favor him much. If it weren’t for you saving him last time, he might have passed away. I believe those who survive great trials are destined for better things."

"Yes," Li Cheng said. "This time, I can only stand by." Though he had once been a retainer of the Prince of Wei, he now had no choice but to stay out of it. He also needed time to recover. His army couldn’t keep fighting endlessly.

Huiyin smiled, "Though you look down on my father, sometimes we should learn from him. Not everything needs to be forced."

Hearing this, Li Cheng also laughed.

Recently, after hearing that Zheng Fang couldn’t stay at home due to Elder Madame Xu’s constant nagging, he went horseback riding to tour the scenery of Xuzhou, still living in great comfort, calling for attendants and servants. He even found Madame Ji’s six-square hat not beautiful enough and specially borrowed a gauze hat from Li Cheng.

The author has something to say:

Everyone may criticize Zheng Fang’s attitude, but they secretly admire how carefree he seems.

title: Chapter 73
content:
Chapter 73

◎Combined Chapter◎

Xie Jiuyi was indeed unable to hold on any longer. Xu Cifei had been very skilled at winning people's allegiance in the past. Her brother claimed to have a personal letter from the Prince of Wei, declaring support for the Prince of Wei’s second son, Li Zhi. At that time, some people who had been dissatisfied and hadn’t gained any benefits under Xie Jiuyi’s leadership once again defected to the Xu family. They even received many promises from Wei Duo. As long as they worked together from the inside, they would help Li Zhi become the heir.

Most ordinary people might find this hard to believe, but there were many who would take risks for official positions and wealth.

This was why Xie Jiuyi lost this battle.

There were too many traitors!

Yin Liyi helped Xie Jiuyi apply medicine and was anxious. "A bunch of ungrateful people. They think they’ll gain something by siding with Wei Duo, but they’re just being used."

"Why get angry, Liyi? I have a plan. Why don’t you go to Yangzhou with the Prince of Yu? If Jianye falls, we can retreat there." Xie Jiuyi had already begun planning.

Yin Liyi shook her head immediately. "I won’t go. I’ll be wherever you are."

She didn’t want to leave him, but Xie Jiuyi reminded her, "You were captured before. What if it happens again and they use you against me?"

"That was an accident. I’ll be very careful this time," Yin Liyi pleaded.

Xie Jiuyi finally relented. "Alright, but the Prince of Yu and your elder sister must leave."

Yin Liyi nodded, determined. "I’ll go talk to them now."

She conveyed Xie Jiuyi’s message to Yin Lifang, who hesitated for a moment but eventually agreed. She then said to Yin Liyi, "Why don’t you come with us? Let’s leave together."

"Sister, what are you saying? I want to stay with my husband. I’ll entrust my children to you." Yin Liyi had always known she wasn’t very clever, but if Wei Duo really attacked, she would stay by her husband’s side. To her, it was a matter of honor and duty.

Yin Lifang stared at her in disbelief. "You were captured before, and now you’re willing to risk it again? You can’t fight, and you’ll only get in the way. Please come with us."

Yin Liyi shook her head. "Sister, I’ve never been as smart as you. If I go to Yangzhou, I’ll just worry for nothing. It’s better for me to stay in Jianye. My husband has promised to find a child around Jing’er’s age for me to raise in the Prince of Wei’s Mansion. That way, no one will know you’ve left."

Yin Lifang finally understood her younger sister’s thoughtful intentions and was deeply moved.

"Maybe we should all stay," Yin Lifang suggested, feeling guilty.

Yin Liyi shook her head firmly. "Sister, you’ve always taken care of me. Now it’s my turn to take care of you."

That night, Yin Lifang left with her son for Yangzhou.

Xie Jiuyi continued to fight, while others watched from the sidelines.

After returning, Li Cheng wasn’t at ease either. With his expanded territory, he couldn’t manage everything personally anymore. He had to think about the bigger picture. Rewards for merits and punishments for crimes had to be balanced, but he couldn’t let small flaws discourage his deserving officials. He was kept extremely busy.

He also recruited a group of advisors to handle specific matters. Liu Gongzi, who had been introduced to Miss Cao, was also recruited under Li Cheng.

These advisors were paid directly by Li Cheng, and he was discussing the external accounts with Huiyin.

"Draft a list, and I’ll handle the seasonal provisions," Huiyin said.

Li Cheng nodded. "I actually want to model it after the imperial court, using the Three Departments and Six Ministries system to manage this place. That way, even if I go on a campaign, things here can still be managed."

Huiyin agreed. "That makes sense. The Three Departments and Six Ministries balance each other. Even if you’re not here, there will still be people to handle things."

However, talented individuals were hard to find. Li Cheng personally prepared for civil and military examinations, not accepting any recommendations.

Knowing that Li Cheng was strict and unapproachable, many turned to Huiyin for help. Madam Mu, who had always been close to Huiyin, came to recommend her youngest son, Munián.

At first, I didn’t want to come, but they insisted I speak to the princess. "My youngest son may not be perfect, but he’s as loyal as they come."

In such matters, Huiyin must remain in high alignment with Li Cheng. She said, "I have long heard that young Master Miao is quite talented. This time, the prince is using a blind selection process, and he will surely appoint people based on their talents."

Madame Miao didn’t dare to blame Huiyin for not putting in a good word. Now that the prince’s territory was growing larger, many people couldn’t even get an audience, so she was lucky to have met with him.

So, she quickly said, "Yes, you are right."

Huiyin said, "Don’t come over these days; it’s better to avoid any appearance of impropriety. Even if your son is truly talented, others might think you’re just trying to pull strings."

Since Huiyin has been turning away visitors, she even told the Zheng family that she would meet them after things settle down.

Madame Ji’s family had relatives who came to seek refuge from Gaoyang, including members of the Xin and Cui families. Especially since the Cui family is related to Li Cheng through his mother’s side, they expected to receive high positions and wealth. However, they soon learned that Li Cheng requires everyone to take exams.

Some people were so full of themselves that they felt insulted by Li Cheng’s exam requirement.

For example, the uncle of the Xin family thought, "I am already a well-known Confucian scholar in Jizhou, yet I have to take exams with the younger generation. It’s too humiliating."

Pei Shuo had to persuade him, "I have already told the prince about your reputation, uncle. Please wait; the prince appoints people based on their talents, and he will surely recruit you."

"With your reassurance, I feel much better." Xin Daru was also eager to serve under a famous lord.

However, Pei Shuo added, "But I can’t guarantee anything. The prince values practical competence over lofty ideals. Uncle, you must be cautious in front of the prince."

As a junior, Pei Shuo couldn’t directly criticize his elder, so after acknowledging Xin Daru, he immediately conveyed Li Cheng’s views, indirectly telling him that Li Cheng was different from Zheng Fang. Zheng Fang came from a humble background and, although talented, wasn’t very sharp or principled, often acting on a whim.

Pei Shuo could still pacify Xin Daru, but Cui Yuehua’s eldest brother sought refuge with Wei Duo, while her second brother came directly to Li Cheng. As a member of the Cui family, he was certainly knowledgeable and prepared at home. Since Zheng Wuheng was in the military, he was young and directly assigned by Li Cheng to the navy to learn naval warfare.

Cui Yuehua was worried but couldn’t say anything to her second brother. Madame Ji seemed to understand what she was thinking and said, "Your second brother is also a famous scholar. The prince doesn’t engage in private meetings, and if he can stand out, it will prove he truly has real talent."

Although the Cui family was closely related to Li Cheng, Li Cheng was indifferent to them, leaving Cui Yuehua uncertain.

"Mother, I was thinking of going to the princess—"

Madame Ji clicked her tongue, "You don’t understand the princess’s temperament; she’s not one to give face. Originally, she had two wet nurses, but one loved to steal and was eventually expelled because she went too far. No one could change her mind."

Her daughter had always been strong-willed since she was young, completely different from De Yin. De Yin, when she was young, enjoyed visiting relatives and friends with elder Madame Xu, but Huiyin would refuse to go anywhere, even if they tried to pull her by carriage. She was resolute and insisted on being herself, even if people called her eccentric.

Later, when her daughter started reading, her perspective on things far surpassed theirs, and Madame Ji found herself listening to her daughter instead.

Cui Yuehua had no choice but to stop talking and went back to talk to nanny Rong, feeling very worried.

Nanny Rong, however, comforted her, "Second Miss, there’s no need to worry. Even if our second master doesn’t pass the exam this time, with our relationship, he will surely meet the prince’s expectations in the future. Blood is thicker than water."

"You’re right." Cui Yuehua felt relieved after hearing this.

After the Cui and Xin families settled down, the Xu family also sought help from elder Madame Xu. Xu Shi’s younger brother originally served under Prince Wei and later returned to his hometown after Prince Wei passed away. The Xu family of Donghai was a large clan and naturally wanted to be re-employed.

Elder Madame Xu didn’t fully understand the external situation and naively agreed, "I’ll just speak to the marquis."

She actually did mention it to Zheng Fang, but he listened with one ear and out the other. He agreed but forgot as soon as he left. These days, the prince’s son-in-law had been sent as an imperial envoy to Yanzhou and Jizhou. His daughter quietly instructed him to gather any misconduct by the governors there and report back to the prince. If he handled this task well, the prince was prepared to grant him a two-thousand-household fief in Jizhou. With that in mind, how could he remember other people’s matters?

Dressed in new clothes, Zheng Fang bid farewell to Li Cheng and headed to Yanzhou and Jizhou.

As soon as he left, Huiyin punched Li Cheng, "You’re really cunning, sending my father away like a rat into a rice jar. With good wine and beautiful women tempting him, how will he remember what he’s supposed to do?"

"That’s exactly the effect I want. If I had sent someone incorruptible, everyone involved would be implicated. Your father’s family has handed over such a large piece of land to me. I was already planning to grant them a fief. If I ever rule the world, there will be even more rewards for you." Li Cheng actually thought the current arrangement was still a bit lacking.

If the fief were over a thousand households, the amount of grain collected would depend on the heavens. In a disaster year, if there was no harvest, there might be nothing. Now, with the Zheng family coming over, they were directly granted grain, the same as the governors of the same state. Zheng Fang was currently in a leisurely position, which didn’t draw attention, making it a very thoughtful arrangement.

Huiyin held his hand. "Let's take it step by step. By the way, are you asking me to go tomorrow as well? That might not be appropriate."

Tomorrow would mark the first "Talent Selection Ceremony" in Li Cheng's territory, an event that had never before allowed women to participate. She was afraid of breaking the rules.

But Li Cheng said, "A wife is a partner. Huiyin, if it weren't for you delivering the supplies last time, our war efforts wouldn't have gone so smoothly. How could you not participate in such a grand event? Without you, it would lose much of its brilliance."

Huiyin felt a joy in her heart and looked at him. "I will do as you wish, My Lord."

For the first exam, Li Cheng personally created the questions on the spot, not revealing them until the candidates had entered. He would randomly point to one and use that as the topic.

Sitting next to Li Cheng, Huiyin was seeing her husband outside of their home for the first time. Not only was he strong in martial strategies, but his literary talent was also exceptional. Although she had studied, listening to him quoting classical texts made her realize how little she knew and how much more she had to learn.

The room was filled with promising scholars and officials, each hoping to prove themselves worthy of serving a future emperor. Nowadays, with Prince Yuzhang still young and the Crown Prince weak, it was the powerful Prince of Huaiyin who really controlled the situation.

After listening to Li Cheng, the candidates were led by officials to their respective examination rooms. It was the first time Huiyin had appeared in front of so many men. As a woman, she felt a bit shy, but also thought it would be shameful to show such timidity, so she steeled herself.

"Don't be afraid."

She heard Li Cheng say to her, and Huiyin nodded seriously.

A man who loves you doesn't just say sweet words or give you trinkets. True love means being willing to include you in his decisions and share his power with you.

She didn't know why Li Cheng had made such a decision, but after the initial fear, she felt excitement.

This was a stark contrast to her previous life, where even as Empress Dowager, her father still held the real power. Outside, there were enemies like Wei Duo, and even her father couldn't handle everything.

Li Cheng was sipping tea with a beauty by his side, not feeling tired at all. He wanted to showcase his full range of talents while making it look effortless.

Unfortunately, Huiyin didn't know what he was thinking.

In contrast, De Yin's situation had become unbearable since her family defected to Li Cheng. One night, while attending to the Crown Prince, she was stripped and brutally whipped with a horsewhip.

Wei Liangdi mocked her, but it was Yunzhi who came to her aid, personally bringing her hot soup.

"Liangdi, fortunately, your title hasn't been stripped yet. Drink some hot soup and rest for a few days." In Yunzhi's view, as long as the title remained, it was best to stay out of the spotlight and focus on staying safe.

Looking at the ginseng soup Yunzhi handed her, De Yin couldn't help but think of how Yunzhi used to be at her beck and call, to the point where even Lu Xiao had to avoid her sharpness. Now, it was the former maid who was rescuing and pitying her. But she didn't show it on her face and said, "I was wrong to treat you badly before."

Yunzhi shook her head. "Liangdi, you're mistaken. I was also wrong to betray my master. But once we step into these palace walls, our only goal is to survive and find a way to live peacefully."

"Oh, thank you. Take care." De Yin looked at her.

Yunzhi quickly left, and the maid serving her said, "Why did you come? You're pregnant. With the whole palace against her, you should have stayed far away."

"Don't talk nonsense."

Hearing this, De Yin couldn't help but resent her family. Why did they all side with Li Cheng, even going so far as to hand over their lands to him? Why were they so biased?

Growing up, she had always been better than her sister Huiyin in every way, but the family had always favored her. She didn't know what kind of torment awaited her, and for the first time, she hated her family so much.

The exams ended nine days later. Some of the weaker candidates were carried out, while others went to pleasure houses to relax amidst the tension of the exams. Some even frantically prayed at temples and Taoist monasteries near Xuzhou, their incense smoke rising.

Even Cui Erlang, from a prestigious family, was anxious. Li Cheng's new system of anonymous marking meant that no one, not even the most well-connected, could influence the results. For those who had previously entered officialdom through patronage or recommendation, failing the exam would be a real disgrace.

Because of this, he even neglected his beloved concubine.

Just as Zheng Wuheng returned and saw his brother-in-law like this, he comforted him. "Brother-in-law, there's no need to worry unnecessarily."

"I'm not worrying without reason. This exam is incredibly rigorous, with the prince and princess personally overseeing every detail, even bathroom breaks. My seat is fine, but some candidates were placed next to the restrooms, which made things quite unpleasant." Cui Erlang knew clearly that this was a gathering of almost all the elites from the Prince of Huaiyin's territory.

Governor of Yuzhou, Guo Zhao, was the most iron-fisted, first organizing an examination in his province with the help of great scholars, selecting fifty candidates to send for further testing. The local administration of Xuzhou was no less strict, and the same went for Yanzhou and Qingzhou. However, the recently annexed Jizhou had not yet organized such a grand event. Cui Erlang had even rejoiced at this, but to his surprise, he saw his brother-in-law from the Zhang family of Jizhou also present.

At the time, both had expressed their disdain for participating in the exam over drinks, but meeting face-to-face at the entrance of the examination hall was truly awkward.

The most awkward scenario would be if his brother-in-law passed while he did not, which would be even more miserable.

Fortunately, neither he nor his brother-in-law passed. Looking up, they saw Li Cheng personally announcing the fifty successful candidates, and one examinee shouted, "I feel like His Highness hasn't finished reading the names, please, Your Highness, read them again..."

These people even knelt before Li Cheng, who silently shook his head, for sometimes the difference between success and failure is as thin as a hair.

Cui Erlang naturally maintained his dignity, but seeing many scholars weeping, he felt deeply distressed.

For over a month, he could not recover from the failure of the exam. Still staying at the Zheng residence, he saw Zheng Fang return with a radiant face, having been well entertained by the Governor of Yuzhou and the Governor of Yanzhou, and received a fief of two thousand dan of grain from the Prince. He truly marveled at how different people's fortunes could be.

Unaware of Cui Erlang's feelings, Zheng Fang said, "Nephew, I've brought back quite a few specialties. You must share them with me."

He then patted Cui Erlang on the shoulder, nearly causing him to stumble backward a few steps.

Leaving aside whether Zheng Fang and Cui Erlang drank together or remained somber, Huaiyin received a note saying that Yin Lifen and her party had arrived in Yangzhou. She immediately handed the note to Li Cheng.

Surprised, Li Cheng asked, "How did you know? Who gave this to you?"

Huaiyin had originally intended to keep this a secret, as one must always have a backup plan. But now, seeing that Li Cheng was willing to share power with her, she decided it was better to reveal her secret now rather than risk being seen as hiding something later.

"I knew you loved the noodles I made, so I thought about opening a noodle shop where those who wanted to eat noodles could go. Later, I planned to use Old Zhang's Noodle Shop to hide grain, making it easier to transport grain to you without being noticed. After we established ourselves in Xuzhou, they occasionally helped me gather information," Huaiyin said, pursing her lips.

Li Cheng coughed heavily, "You are far more capable than I imagined."

In truth, his heart was already in turmoil. Last time, when Huaiyin arranged for grain to be transported, she personally negotiated with the grain merchants and oversaw the entire process, not flinching at the cost of five hundred thousand taels. Despite not being fabulously wealthy, she never considered failure and was very clear-headed in important matters.

"But how does a regular noodle shop know such confidential stuff?"

Huiyin smiled. "Don't think the lower classes know nothing. They went to Yangzhou and needed to buy people. Our Zhang Laosan's noodle shop is often in the busiest markets, with locations in every nook and cranny. People from all walks of life, including gossipers, are always in the loop."

"You've got a point," Li Cheng replied, realizing that while he thought highly of himself, Huiyin was far more composed and had her own wisdom.

She wasn't a know-it-all, but she always had her clever tricks.

Seeing him so serious, Huiyin couldn't help but say, "We usually joke around, but now you sound so serious."

"Hey, do you think Xie Jiuyi is losing his nerve?" Li Cheng asked.

"I think so. You only took Wu County; you didn't touch any other territories of Prince Wei. With Zhao Hong's sudden death, Xie Jiuyi should have been feeling confident." Huiyin couldn't understand it.

Li Cheng said, "Let's see how the situation develops. I heard the emperor's health is deteriorating."

In fact, in their previous life, the emperor had already passed away. It was strange that in this life, the emperor was still clinging to life. But Huiyin thought that even if she had killed Li Heng in her previous life, the world hadn't found peace.

Taking things one step at a time felt more reliable.

"Honey, even if he becomes emperor, will people follow his orders?" Huiyin asked.

"It doesn't matter. I heard Wei Liangdi gave birth to a son. Wei Duo probably wants to control the emperor to command the vassals; he won't let Li Heng survive so easily."

"That's true, but how do we get Wei Duo to make a decision?" Huiyin didn't understand.

Li Cheng smiled. "In the past, Su Qin and Zhang Yi used their eloquence to persuade the King of Chu. How could I not have planted some influential figures? Don't worry, I've got this covered."

"So you've already made plans, but Wei Duo is still at war with Xie Jiuyi?" Huiyin still felt she couldn't see through it all.

The strategies of diplomacy and warfare between the warring states were something that Huiyin had read about in works like the *Zuo Zhuan*, but she still found some aspects confusing.

Li Cheng explained to her in detail: "If I were to directly oppose Li Heng, he holds the legitimacy, and I would easily become the target of public criticism, called a usurper. Even a thousand years from now, the historical records would describe me that way. No matter how much I achieve, this kind of infamy would stick, and I would be attacked by all. But if Wei Duo makes the first move, and I then deal with him, no one can argue with that."

"But what if Xie Jiuyi becomes too powerful?" Huiyin asked.

Li Cheng shook his head. "That would be problematic. Wei is no longer under the control of the King of Wei. Consort Xu and others have rebelled, leaving Wei in chaos. Now, as they fight among themselves, I need to focus on rebuilding my strength, especially since we’ve only just regained Jizhou. When the time comes to advance from Jizhou to Shangjing, it will be easy for me."

Huiyin listened, but only partially understood, and privately pondered the matter.

About ten days later, Li Cheng returned to say that Wei Duo had sent men to capture Yin Liyi in order to force Xie Jiuyi to withdraw his troops.

Huiyin was left speechless. Yin Liyi isn’t trained in warfare, so why would she be taken to the front lines? It was clearly the same old tactic.

title: Chapter 74
content:
Chapter 74

**Updated Chapter**

Xie Jiuyi hadn’t expected Wei Duo to resort to such underhanded tactics. The couple had everything planned out. They arranged for Yin Liyi to move into the Prince of Wei’s Mansion with the child, pretending that everything was as it had been when Yin Lifang and the others were there, with heavy guards stationed for protection.

The situation went awry because Yin Liyi believed she wasn’t really in any danger. After staying in the Prince of Wei’s Mansion for so long, she felt stifled. In the past, when she was in Jianye, she would often go to tea houses, watch plays, or buy street snacks. She had no class prejudice and simply loved street food.

She wanted to go out, but Xie Jiuyi advised her not to. So, she called for a street vendor to come inside instead. Unbeknownst to her, the vendor was actually someone in disguise, and she was knocked out and taken away.

This was Yin Liyi’s second time being captured, and she found it almost laughable. Her luck was truly terrible. She didn’t know what the old villain Wei Duo would use to threaten her, and she could only hope that Xie Jiuyi wouldn’t agree to anything.

However, Xie Jiuyi was also in a difficult position. His troops weren’t entirely loyal to him. If he withdrew them for the sake of his wife, people would surely gossip about it in the future. But if he didn’t withdraw, his wife would likely be killed.

Unfortunately, those under him disagreed. Someone said, “Let’s secretly send people to rescue the lady while attacking on the surface, letting Wei Duo know you don’t care about your wife. That way, he won’t dare harm her.”

“Yes, I remember when the lady was captured in Yuzhou last time, Young Prince Li didn’t care either. The more you act indifferent, the more leeway you have.”

Even now, people in Wei still referred to Li Cheng as Young Prince.

Xie Jiuyi used to blame Li Cheng for not caring about his wife’s life, but now he was in the same situation.

Wei Duo was well-versed in the art of deception in warfare. He had already discovered that Xie Jiuyi had defied his family to marry Yin Liyi, showing deep affection. This reminded him of the story of Shen Gong Wuchen and Xia Ji. Xia Ji had brought down several countries.

Naturally, Wei Duo had seen Yin Liyi once. She was indeed beautiful, but she had a strong will.

However, he knew that if he kept Xie Jiuyi hanging like this, it would be fine, but if he really took her, it would become a deadly feud. He didn’t want to see a united Xie family army. Thinking of this, Wei Duo personally led his troops again, hoping that Xie Jiuyi would attack.

Xie Jiuyi and Wei Duo were fighting fiercely with no sign of stopping. When Yin Liyi found out, she didn’t blame Li Cheng as she used to. She understood clearly that if Xie Jiuyi abandoned the city for her, it would be an act of betrayal.

Her double standards were unknown to Li Cheng, who expected Xie Jiuyi to continue attacking without being affected by Yin Liyi.

Huiyin was upset: “That Yin woman stayed at my house for a few days after you rescued her. Although she didn’t show it in front of me, I could see that she still thought you weren’t doing enough. Why does Yin Liyi have particularly high expectations of you?”

If it were Yin Lifang, it would make sense. Li Cheng had indeed sent her generous gifts, saved her son, and even had a past marriage with her. But what did he have to do with Yin Liyi?

She really didn’t understand.

Li Cheng, being a thorough person, pondered for a long time before saying, “She came to my house when she was young. My mother treated the Yin sisters well because of Yin Lifang. Later, when the Prince of Wei asked me to manage his estate, I took care of them because of familiarity, thinking I would marry Yin Lifang. I guess she sees me as someone who gives unconditionally. In this world, people have high expectations of good people. If you do something slightly wrong, you’ll be blamed. But if you’re a bad person and do one good thing, many will remember your kindness.”

Huiyin thought what he said made sense but couldn’t help but laugh: “There’s also a possibility that she thinks making you do things for her highlights her own charm.”

Some women like to prove their charm by making men do things for them.

Although it’s not right to talk about people behind their backs, she couldn’t help but remember how Yin Liyi’s family had many complaints after Li Cheng rescued them. Huiyin had no kind words for them.

But this kind of talk made Li Cheng feel nauseous. Seeing that he was unwell, Huiyin quickly poured him a cup of tea: “Are you feeling unwell? Should I get you some lychee drink, which you love?”

“I’m just disgusted. Don’t worry, I’m fine.” Li Cheng really felt like dying after thinking he was being used by a fool.

Huiyin gently patted his back: “Don’t say disgusting. Actually, she’s quite pitiful too. Forget it, let’s not talk about her anymore. Your cousin Cui Erlang has sent his visiting cards several times. Do you want to meet him?”

Li Cheng hadn’t had time to deal with Cui Erlang. His relationship with his uncle’s family was generally distant, but since Huiyin asked, considering they were relatives, he said, “Alright, I’ll make time to invite him over.”

“Well, you handle that yourself. By the way, have the positions for the people selected through the imperial examinations been assigned?” Huiyin asked.

She used to be very careful not to ask about outside matters, fearing Li Cheng would be wary, but now that they were open with each other as a couple, there was nothing to be cautious about.

Li Cheng laughed: “Don’t worry, I’ll have someone present a handbook specifically for you.”

Naturally, Li Cheng had his own plans for these young men from influential families who came with their own resources. When he met Cui Erlang, he shared his intentions: "After failing the imperial examination, what do you intend to do, Zhiqing (Cui Erlang's courtesy name)?"

Although Cui Erlang was his cousin, he dared not be presumptuous. He straightened himself and replied, "I have been studying hard at home, preparing for next year's examination."

Li Cheng smiled and nodded, saying, "The 'Qin Shi' says, seeing a worthy person but not recommending them, or recommending them but not employing them promptly, is a slight."

Cui Erlang's eyes lit up, realizing that Li Cheng intended to give him a significant role.

"I will follow your instructions, Prince," Cui Erlang said.

Li Cheng smiled and continued, "Out of the fifty who passed the imperial examination, twenty will stay by my side, and thirty will be appointed to various prefectures. As far as I know, Taicang County already has a county magistrate but is in need of a deputy. Would you find that position unsuitable, Zhiqing?"

Cui Erlang thought for a moment. Taicang was part of Wu Commandery, a prosperous area, and it seemed like a good opportunity, so he rose to express his gratitude.

Li Cheng further instructed, "I am assigning you there not only because I value your talent but also to see your capabilities. If you prove yourself, there will be no need for further examinations; I will employ you significantly."

Being a deputy is the best way to test one's character and resolve. The one who gets things done is often the deputy, whose efforts might be claimed by the superior or blamed if things go wrong. Li Cheng valued knowledge but placed even greater emphasis on personal ability. Young men from aristocratic families like Cui Erlang, who had been exposed to officialdom and the everyday conduct of elders, could become talents if properly honed.

Now that Cui Erlang's home in Jizhou had come under Li Cheng's control, he felt immediately ambitious upon hearing Li Cheng's candid words.

Similarly, there was the son of Miao Furen, who also failed the military examination, ending up just outside the top fifty. The first fifty were either assigned to various governors or military units, leaving him without a position. Therefore, Li Cheng arranged for Miao Xiao Lang to serve as a judicial magistrate in Hejian Prefecture of Jizhou.

These young men from aristocratic families held relatively low positions. Cui Erlang, as a deputy magistrate, was of the eighth rank, and the judicial magistrate was of the ninth rank. Both came with family-provided advisors.

At first, Miao Furen felt her son had missed out, but now that he was appointed to Hejian, she hurried to the mansion to express her gratitude. "Amita Buddha, I can finally rest easy knowing my son has been given a position," she said.

"Indeed, the Prince also found young Master Miao quite unfortunate, so when he learned of the vacancy in Hejian, he immediately sent him there. Jizhou is a new prefecture, and Hejian is one of the best among the nine commanderies. Let young Master Miao work hard there, and he will achieve success," Huiyin replied.

Now, all the former officials had to be replaced. Li Cheng preferred to employ young people and disliked using seasoned officials.

Miao Furen smiled and said, "We owe this all to you. Otherwise, who would remember our young master?"

"Please don't say that. It is Master Miao's own ability," Huiyin replied.

After securing his position, Cui Erlang lifted his spirits and regained his usual energy. Although Cui Yuehua found the position somewhat lowly, Cui Erlang had a better understanding.

Those who have never held office might dismiss eighth or ninth-rank positions as insignificant, but when you actually get a post, any official position is a blessing. This was no longer an era dominated by aristocratic families. If a family of high status lacked talent, they would decline within a few generations.

Just as someone who has never earned money might think a few hundred coins a month is small, but once they start earning it, they realize how difficult it is to make even a few hundred wen.

Thus, Cui Erlang said, "Since I didn't pass, should I expect to be appointed as a governor?"

"Brother, our family has a special relationship with the Prince," Cui Yuehua replied, thinking of their dual familial connection and not wanting to benefit outsiders.

Cui Erlang explained, "After our aunt passed away, my father could not come to assist the Prince. The Prince relied on himself to achieve his current status. I am not like our elder brother, who is renowned for his talent. Being able to serve in Taicang is already due to this relationship. Taicang was where the Wu Kingdom once stored grain in granaries; being assigned there is a significant opportunity, and I am delighted."

Cui Yuehua realized this and said, "I see."

"Be careful with your words. When you were younger and living at home, and later after marrying into the family of the Marquis of Zhaojie in Jizhou, you were treated with great respect. But here, in the domain of the Princess of Huaiyin, a single wrong word could lead to resentment. Don't think that just because you speak cautiously, there won't be consequences. There's no such thing as a secret that doesn't eventually get out," Cui Erlang advised his sister.

With no family nearby and being young, Cui Yuehua had a supportive husband and a mother-in-law who treated her like a daughter. Now, hearing her brother's words, it was as if a revelation had struck her.

Having family to guide and support you is invaluable. The same could be seen with Huiyin. Pei Shuo was now serving at the main camp in Xuzhou and had become a trusted person of Li Cheng. Whenever he came to the mansion to speak with Li Cheng, he would also visit the rear courtyard to exchange a few words with Huiyin.

Currently, Pei Shuo remarked, "I noticed some swelling on your face and dark circles under your eyes, Sister. I imagine you're not sleeping well and are hungry. Your health is more important than anything else, so please take care, Sister."

"Brother, what are you saying?" Huiyin was still feeling a mix of embarrassment and frustration.

She was tall and strong, completely unlike the delicate women of Jiangnan, so she also wanted to lose some weight. But losing weight meant eating less, and if she ate less in the evening, she wouldn’t be able to sleep.

Back when she was at home, Huiyin and Elder Madame Xu would say she was robust, and Huiyin had secretly tried to lose weight, which Pei Shuo was also aware of.

Pei Shuo smiled and said, "I really shouldn’t say this, as I am a man after all, but for someone like you, sister, to worry about such things is truly unnecessary."

"That’s because after I sprained my waist and spent those days lying on the couch, I started eating without restraint, and before I knew it, I started to gain weight. I can’t even fit into last year’s clothes anymore," Huiyin complained.

Pei Shuo then said, "That’s exactly why you need more rest, so you’ll have more energy. If you don’t eat enough, your energy levels will drop, and you’ll crave food to compensate."

After their conversation, Huiyin thanked Pei Shuo for his concern. Unexpectedly, a few days later, Pei Shuo specially sent a chef to help Huiyin with her diet.

"This way, you won’t go hungry, and you won’t gain weight. This chef is reliable and has been thoroughly vetted, so you can use him with confidence," Pei Shuo said.

Huiyin happily said, "If it works, I will definitely thank you with a grand gift, brother."

Pei Shuo shook his head, "I just hope you stay healthy, that’s all I wish for."

The chef he sent prepared a type of steamed bun made from coarse grains for breakfast, the size of a palm, with just two types of vegetables and a boiled egg. Lunch was half a bowl of rice, a portion of lean meat, two types of vegetables, and dinner was the same as lunch.

Li Cheng was gnawing on a lamb leg beside her and cut off a small piece with a dagger, asking, "How about it? Want a piece?"

"No, I need to control my eating," Huiyin quickly shook her head, then added, "Tomorrow, the kitchen will prepare stir-fried lamb with stuffed dumplings."

Li Cheng sighed, "I’ve told you not to worry. It’s better to ride horses. Honestly, I eat more than you, but because I practice martial arts and horse archery daily, no one says I’m fat."

Huiyin didn’t know what to say. "You’re not just not fat, you’re extremely lean."

In fact, Li Cheng thought Huiyin was already stunningly beautiful, but considering there were many women who wanted to marry him, he guessed his wife might lack confidence. So he said, "But what I love most is your body. If you were to lose weight, it would really not look good."

"Don’t try to flatter me. I don’t care, I want to lose weight to how I was before." After eating those dishes for a month, she had made significant progress.

Seeing that her jawline had become sharper, she was about to call Li Cheng when he walked in and said, "Guess what? Xie Jiuyi couldn’t beat Wei Duo. He barely won one battle. Wei Duo, like Zhang Song, put Yin Liyi in front of his horse, but Xie Jiuyi, being her husband, exposed a vulnerability..."
